Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposal focuses on three directions: intense structures in fluid flows, mixing by fluid flows, and effects of chemical attraction in biology, ecology and medicine. Fluid flows exhibit high degree of complexity and can easily develop intense structures. Better fundamental understanding of the mechanisms of creation of intense features in fluid flows is very important for many applications in engineering, weather forecasting and other fields. The first direction of the proposal seeks to study classical equations of fluid mechanics focussing on situations where intense fluid motion can develop spontaneously. Recent novel results obtained by the PI in this direction provide hopes for an essential advance in understanding these complex and important phenomena. In the second direction, a study of most efficient ways of mixing in fluid flow is proposed. Efficient mixing is of critical importance in many applications, ranging from combustion in engines to ecology. In the third direction, the PI will study the role of chemical sensing and chemical attraction for enhancement of reactions in biology. One situation where it is relevant involves healing of the body, where infected or injured tissues releases special compounds which attract immune system cells to fight the infection. Chemical attraction can also be an undesirable effect: some tumors are known to rely on this mechanism for their growth. The PI plans to develop new mathematical tools to analyze these more advanced and better predictive models. The project involves a training component, where junior researchers at all levels will be mentored as scholars and educators and will work on research projects under the guidance of the PI.

The first main focus of the proposal is on studying solutions of the classical equations of fluid mechanics, such as incompressible Euler, Navier-Stokes and 2D Boussinesq system. Recent numerical simulations of Hou and Luo suggest a new scenario for singularity formation for solutions of the 3D Euler equation. The scenario is axi-symmetric, and singularity formation happens at the boundary. The scenario also applies for the 2D inviscid Boussinesq system. Inspired by the geometry of the scenario, the PI (jointly with Vladimir Sverak) has constructed examples of solutions of 2D Euler equation with double exponential growth in vorticity gradient. Such growth is known to be sharp. The PI intends to use new insights obtained in the construction to approach more complex and long open questions for 2D Boussinesq system and 3D Euler equation. Methods employed will include functional analysis, Fourier analysis, PDE techniques and novel comparison principles. The second direction concerns efficiency of mixing in fluids given constraints on fluid velocity. Bounds on the mixing rates under various types of constraints and boundary conditions as well as insight into the nature of best mixing flows will be sought. This area lies at the intersection of dynamical systems, PDE and Fourier analysis. The third direction involves effects of chemical attraction between reacting species on the rates of reaction. Chemical attraction will be modeled by the Keller-Segel and related nonlinear terms. The PI proposes to obtain qualitative results about the behavior of solutions in such systems, and to derive precise bounds describing the strength of the effect and its dependence on various key parameters. Sharp bounds on convergence to equlibirum for Fokker-Planck operators with certain natural classes of potentials will also be obtained.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project is in the area of mathematical fluid mechanics. Fluids are all around us, and we can witnessthe complexity and subtleness of their properties in every day life, in ubiquitous technology, and in dramatic phenomena such as tornado or hurricane. Equations describing how fluids move were one of the first ones to be written down in the 18th century, and much research has been focused on this area. Nevertheless, some of the fundamental equations of fluids mechanics remain poorly understood. This is largely due to the complicated nature of the underlying phenomena, which on the level of the mathematics is reflected in nonlinearity, non-locality and high computational complexity. 

The project involved two main directions. In the first direction, the focus was on analysis solutions of the incompressible Euler and surface quasi-geostrophic (SQG) equations. The incompressible Euler equation is one of the most fundamental equations of fluid dynamics, it describes flow of volume preserving and inviscid fluid and is widely used in applications. The SQG equation and its variants come from atmospheric science, where, under a number of simplifying assumptions, it described evolution of the temperature on the surface of a planet. The main function of a partial differential equation (PDE) such as Euler equation is, given some initial data, to allow us to compute the solution and use it for prediction of future behavior of the fluid.This is exactly how weather forecasting works, or how new airplane shapes are designed. Therefore, the first basic question one can ask about a PDE is existence and uniqueness of solutions in some appropriate class. This question closely linked to singularity formation, and more generally to creation of small scales in solutions. If solution forms a singularity (meaning that some quantity becomes infinite) or develops very fine features, it becomes very difficult to compute, analyze, and forecast. Understanding singularities is important becasue they correspond to intense fluid motion and may signify important physical phenomena, or warn about breakdown of the model. If the solutions to equation cannot form singularities, the equation is called globally regular. 

The project resulted in significant advances in understanding singularity formation process in solutions of the Euler and SQG equations, and some associated models. The first ever examples of finite time singularity formation in patch solutions of the modified SQG equation have been constructed. New models of the Euler equation have been desgined, and examples of finite time singularity formation have been exhibited for these models, providing insight into possible blow up scenarios for the Euler equation.

In the second direction, research focused on chemotaxis in fluid flow. Chemotaxis is a directed motion of cells attracted by certain chemical. Some bacteria and mold use this mechanism to produce self-organized motion that helps their survival. One of the most celebrated models of chemotaxis is the Keller-Segel model, which predicts finite time singularity in solutions if the total initial mass of mold is sufificiently high. This corresponds to mold reaching extremely high concentration and assembling a fruit body used for transport towards regions with better resources. The project work analyzed this process taking place in a fluid flow. The results show that mixing due to fluid flow can significantly influence the assembly process, and in particular arrest singularity formation.    

The project resulted in numerous activities for junior researchers on all levels. Two postdoctoral researchers have succesfully moved on to tenure-track positions. Two graduate students have obtained PhD degrees and moved on to postdoctoral positions. Three undergraduate students have participated in a succesful REU project.
